introPages.title: Comparatives and superlatives: basics
introPages.body:
Comparative = comparing two things: bigger, more expensive, better. Superlative = comparing three or more: biggest, most expensive, best.

Short adjectives: add -er / -est (big → bigger, biggest). Long adjectives: more / most + adjective (expensive → more expensive, most expensive).

In Part 2, gaps often test intensifiers before comparatives (much, far, a lot) or the before superlatives.

introPages.title: Intensifiers and the superlative
introPages.body:
Intensifiers before comparatives: much, far, a lot, even, still make the comparison stronger. Much better, far more important, even worse.

Never use more with -er: ❌ more bigger → ✓ much bigger. Never double the comparative: ❌ more better → ✓ much better.

Superlative + the: the best, the most important, the biggest. The gap often needs the before a superlative.

introPages.title: As … as and the same … as
introPages.body:
As … as = equality: as good as, as much as, as tall as. Both as are required. ❌ as good that → ✓ as good as.

The same … as: the same as, the same size as, the same colour as. Use as, not than. ❌ the same than → ✓ the same as.

introPages.title: Less vs fewer, and irregular forms
introPages.body:
Less + uncountable: less time, less money. Fewer + countable plural: fewer people, fewer reasons. ❌ less reasons → ✓ fewer reasons.

Irregular: good → better, best; bad → worse, worst; much/many → more, most; little → less, least. The better of the two (not the best of the two) when comparing exactly two.

introPages.title: Rules for the gap
introPages.body:
• Before a comparative? → much, far, a lot, even, still (not more with -er).
  • Before a superlative? → the.
  • Equality? → as … as (both as needed).
  • The same + ? + comparison? → as (the same as, the same size as).
  • Countable plural + less? → use fewer.

mcQuiz.question: In It's ___ better now, which intensifier fits before the comparative?
mcQuiz.explanation: Much, far, a lot intensify comparatives. Never 'more better'.

mcQuiz.question: In This is ___ best option, which word fits before the superlative?
mcQuiz.explanation: Superlatives take 'the': the best, the most important.

mcQuiz.question: In He's as tall ___ his brother, which word fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: As … as – the second 'as' is required.

mcQuiz.question: In It's the same size ___ mine, which word fits?
Is more bigger correct?
options: No – use much bigger or bigger
mcQuiz.explanation: Never use 'more' with -er. Use 'much bigger' or just 'bigger'.

mcQuiz.question: In There are ___ reasons now, which fits? (countable plural)
When comparing exactly two, we say the ___ of the two. Which form?
mcQuiz.explanation: For two things, use the comparative: the better of the two.

shortQuestions.question: This is the most good option.
shortQuestions.explanation: Good has irregular superlative: best (not most good).

shortQuestions.question: He's as tall that his brother.
accepted: he's as tall as his brother
shortQuestions.explanation: As … as – both 'as' are required. Not 'that'.

shortQuestions.question: It's the same size than mine.
accepted: it's the same size as mine

shortQuestions.question: There are less reasons to worry.
accepted: there are fewer reasons to worry

shortQuestions.question: It's much more easier.
shortQuestions.explanation: Never use 'more' with -er form. Use 'much easier'.

shortQuestions.question: She's the best of the two.
accepted: she's the better of the two
shortQuestions.explanation: When comparing exactly two, use the comparative: the better of the two.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why can't we say 'more better' or 'more bigger'?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: We never combine 'more' with the -er form. Use 'much' + comparative (much better, much bigger), or just the comparative alone. 'More' is used with long adjectives: more expensive.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the difference between less and fewer.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Less + uncountable nouns (less time, less water). Fewer + countable plurals (fewer people, fewer reasons). 'Less reasons' is wrong; use 'fewer reasons'.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When do we use the better instead of the best?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: When comparing exactly two things: the better of the two, the more expensive of the two. With three or more, use the superlative: the best of the three.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is wrong with 'as good that'?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: The structure is 'as … as'. Both 'as' are required. 'As good as' is correct. 'That' or 'than' cannot replace the second 'as'.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three intensifiers that can go before a comparative.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Much, far, a lot, even, still. e.g. much better, far more important, even worse.
